IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: To end poverty and injustice, and to restore dignity and hope in the world's poorest communities.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Tearfund USA (the organization) is a Christian international relief and development charity working globally to end poverty and injustice, and to restore dignity and hope in the world's poorest communities.
IRS990.Desc: Mobilization and advocacy: Tearfund USA hosted pastor and leader gatherings to explore themes of justice and action around gender equity, racial equality, and climate justice. This involved events with 20+ churches inviting leaders to take further action with studies, signing petitions, and conferences. The organization also hosted The Justice Conference 2022 in Denver, Colorado. This brought together 440 individuals on similar themes and for spiritual renewal. Additionally, Tearfund USA sent a Board Director and church partner to join a global climate forum in Kenya. Tearfund USA also launched the Live Justly curriculum via hardcopy and e-book, making it broadly available to churches and individuals.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Church and community transformation (CCT): In partnership with Tearfund (UK) and other NGOs, the organization supported church mobilization and community transformation initiatives in Central America and Malawi. In Central America, 1030 people were reached and 412 churches engaged. In Malawi, 6 theological colleges and 26 facilitators were trained, and 704 churches engaged. The organization also collaborated on a training for another global NGO, which took place for their field staff and partners in Kenya; trained another NGO in Cambodia; and supported church and community transformation in Asia. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Conflict, Crisis and Refugees: The organization mobilized financial support in response to key global humanitarian events. This included partnering with another NGO to raise support for Ukraine; funding hurricane response in Puerto Rico; mobilizing support for the earthquake in Turkey and Syria, flooding in Pakistan, ongoing crises in Lebanon, Yemen, and East Africa; and mobilizing support for peace in the DRC. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

ProgSrvcAccomActyOtherGrp.Desc: Gender Equality & Racial Justice: Tearfund USA joined forces with other NGOs in a coalition to launch a global gender justice initiative aimed at advocating for greater gender equity throughout global development; the organization provided the administrative infrastructure and hosted an inaugural 120-member event. It supported 5 small-scale community organization grants aimed at accelerating the impact of grassroots organizations led by and impacting communities of color. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

Environmental and Economic Sustainability: Tearfund USA also partnered with local organizations in Guatemala, Haiti and Mozambique to advance economic and sustainable livelihoods. It also finalized a multi-year partnership expanding savings groups in Burkina Faso and Chad, West Africa. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule A, Part II Schedule A, Part II, Columns (a) - (e):
Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: Per the instructions public support is measured using a 5-year computation period that includes the current and four prior tax years (including short years). The organization had a short year in 2019. The below chart clarifies the information represented in Schedule A, Part II: Column (a) - 10 month period ending 3/31/19 Column (b) - Fiscal year ending 03/31/20 Column (c) - Fiscal year ending 03/31/21 Column (d) - Fiscal year ending 03/31/22 Column (e) - Fiscal year ending 03/31/23

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule F, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Tearfund monitors and evaluates activities and outcomes based on the terms of the grant and provides quarterly reports to Tearfund USA on all programmatic activities.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2 Procedures for monitoring use of grant funds.
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: US grant recipients are required to: 1) be a registered 501c3 organization 2) report on expenditures 3) provide a copy of any audited statement of finances for the project

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: (Expenses $ 130,675 including grants of $ 25,398) Gender Equality & Racial Justice: Tearfund USA joined forces with other NGOs in a coalition to launch a global gender justice initiative aimed at advocating for greater gender equity throughout global development; the organization provided the administrative infrastructure and hosted an inaugural 120-member event. It supported 5 small-scale community organization grants aimed at accelerating the impact of grassroots organizations led by and impacting communities of color. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part III, Line 4d Description of other program services
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: (Expenses $ 50,523 including grants of $ 50,523) Environmental and Economic Sustainability: Tearfund USA also partnered with local organizations in Guatemala, Haiti and Mozambique to advance economic and sustainable livelihoods. It also finalized a multi-year partnership expanding savings groups in Burkina Faso and Chad, West Africa. Tearfund USA's grant activity supports these activities around the world.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 6 Classes of members or stockholders
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The corporation shall have one class of members whose rights, powers, and duties shall be as specified herein and in the bylaws. There shall initially be one member of the corporation. The duly appointed and currently serving Chair of the Board of Tearfund, Incorporated in England and Wales and registered with the Charity Commission of England and Wales shall serve as such initial member.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 7a Members or stockholders electing members of governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Chair of the Board of Tearfund in the UK, as the sole member of Tearfund USA, holds the authority to appoint or remove directors on the Tearfund USA Board. Should the Tearfund in the UK Chair choose to waive his/her right to make appointments, Tearfund USA Board members would be elected by the current directors/trustees of the Tearfund USA Board.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 7b Decisions requiring approval by members or stockholders
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The corporation may be dissolved by the Board with the approval of the sole member (or two-thirds majority of all members if additional were to be appointed). Alternatively, the member(s) may act alone to dissolve the organization by their unanimous written consent.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 8b Documentation of meetings held by committees of governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The organization has no committees with authority to act on behalf of the governing body. Therefore, this line was answered no in accordance with the instructions.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 11b Review of form 990 by governing body
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: A copy of the Form 990 is provided and reviewed by the organization's Treasurer and the full board of directors prior to filing with the Internal Revenue Service.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 12c Conflict of interest policy
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: All the organization's staff and board members will perform their duties and conduct their private life in a manner that ensures possible conflicts of interest with their role in the organization are avoided or managed appropriately. Conflicts of interest that are undeclared or improperly managed result in risks to the work of the organization, including financial risks, legal risks, moral risks (conduct that would be considered unethical or illegal), reputational risks (conduct that may undermine donor or supporter confidence in the organization) and compliance risks (conduct that may put us in breach of our regulatory duties to donors or other third parties). The board of directors and all officers of the organization are required to annually sign a statement stating they have read and intend to comply with the board-approved conflict of interest policy. All staff and board members must comply with this policy. Failure to comply will be treated as a misconduct issue for staff and may result in the removal of a board member and staff, depending upon the severity of any breach. The signed statements are reviewed by the Secretary and CEO. Should any potential conflicts of interest be disclosed, the board member or officer would be asked to refrain from participation in any deliberation or decision with regard to matters affected by the relationship.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15a Process to establish compensation of top management official
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The independent members of the Board approves compensation for the CEO using comparability data from an independent recruitment firm that provided input based on market value and salary benchmarking. The approval process is documented in the board minutes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 15b Process to establish compensation of other employees
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The CEO proposes and the Board approves the compensation for other officers including the Vice President and Director of Operations. Comparability data is consulted when determining compensation. This approval is documented in the board minutes.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Line 19 Required documents available to the public
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The governing documents, conflict of interest policy, and financial statements are available upon request.
While grants to 6 separate regions appear in Schedule F, Part II, all funds are granted to one foreign 501(c)(3) equivalent for use in the regions listed.
Emily Sarmiento, President & CEO, was replaced by Daniel Valle, after the end of this tax period, 3/31/23. Accordingly, Daniel Valle is not reported on Form 990, Part VII, during this tax period.

IdRelatedTaxExemptOrgGrp.PrimaryActivitiesTxt: Helping eradicate poverty & provide disaster relief internationally
